media.title: Nasa launches InSight lander on mission to Mars - video
media.description:
The Mars InSight lander will take more than six months to travel the 300m miles to Mars where it will start geological excavations. It will dig deeper into Mars than ever before – about 5 metres – to record the planet’s temperature. It will also place a hi-tech seismometer on the surface of the planet to try to measure quakes

• Nasa launches InSight spacecraft to explore the insides of Mars

tags: NASA's Insight lander blasts off to Mars
Nasa launches InSight spacecraft to explore the insides of Mars

media.trailText: Nasa launches spacecraft from California on unprecedented geological mission to explore planet

results.title: Nasa launches InSight lander on mission to Mars - video

media.title: Why is the NRA so powerful? – video
media.description: The National Rifle Association (NRA) is famous for its influence on American politics. Under its executive vice-president, Wayne LaPierre, the group has resisted changes to gun legislation for more than four decades, despite multiple mass shootings. Here's how the group keeps the status quo
media.trailText: The National Rifle Association is famous for its influence on American politics.

results.title: Why is the NRA so powerful? – video

media.title: The 'hostile environment' made me feel like an alien: Windrush victim – video
media.description: Paulette Wilson and her daughter Natalie Barnes speak about how the Home Office's policy affected them after Paulette, who moved to the UK from Jamaica in 1968 when she was 10 and has never left, was classed as an illegal immigrant, taken to the Yarl’s Wood removal centre and threatened with deportation
media.trailText: Paulette Wilson and her daughter Natalie Barnes speak about how the Home Office's immigration policy affected them

results.title: The 'hostile environment' made me feel like an alien: Windrush victim – video

media.title: Bending time: The hidden dimension of time-lapse photography – video
media.description:
Guardian Australia heads to the picturesque foreshores of Sydney Harbour to discuss the art of time-lapse photography with Matthew Vandeputte, a Belgian-born photographer who has made a name for himself pushing the technique to its limits.

Using the Sydney Opera House and Harbour Bridge as subjects, Vandeputte talks through the process, saying it reveals a 'hidden dimension that we're living in, but not aware of'
media.trailText: Guardian Australia heads to the picturesque foreshores of Sydney Harbour to discuss the art of time-lapse photography with Matthew Vandeputte

results.title: Bending time: The hidden dimension of time-lapse photography – video

media.title: Trump's NRA speech: Kanye West, North Korea and London's 'war zone' – video
media.description:
Donald Trump delivered a wideranging speech to the annual National Rifle Association meeting in Dallas on Friday. Urging Republicans to vote in the midterms, the president told the cheering crowd that their 'second amendment rights are under siege but they will never ever be under siege as long as I'm your president' 

  • Donald Trump brags of achievements and promises NRA: I'll defend gun rights
media.trailText: Donald Trump tells a cheering NRA crowd that their second amendment rights are under siege, issuing the rallying cry: 'but they will never ever be under siege as long as I'm your president'

results.title: Trump's NRA speech: Kanye West, North Korea and London's 'war zone' – video

results.defaultHtml:
Status quo prevails on night of no real victors

By early morning Labour had gained seats but failed to make the advances it had hoped for in London. The Conservatives lost seats but were relieved to cling on to key councils. Brandon Lewis, the Conservative party chairman, said his party had a “reasonable night, a good night”. Jeremy Corbyn celebrated seizing Plymouth council and said he was "delighted" by the result. One pollster estimated that a general election matching these results would see Labour with a similar number of seats to the 262 it scored in 2017, while the Tories would lose 12.

Tories lose control of Trafford stronghold

Surprise success for two Green candidates against Conservative incumbents helped Labour become the biggest party in the Manchester council, one of its biggest successes of the night. "I’m absolutely ecstatic,” said Andrew Western, the leader of the Labour group on Trafford council. “This is far beyond our expectations."

Labour's Barnet defeat blamed on antisemitism row

Hoping for a 1.6% swing and one additional seat to win Barnet from no overall control, Labour instead saw the council move into the Conservative column. Party activists in the area - which has a significant Jewish population - blamed the antisemitism row that has engulfed the capital. Defeated Labour councillor Adam Langleben called for Jeremy Corbyn to apologise to Jewish activists, adding: "We as Jewish Labour activists were told we were endorsing anti-semitism."

Modest success for Lib Dems in remain areas

The party celebrated as it took control of Richmond by gaining 22 seats and had some other good results. Ed Davey, the party’s home affairs spokesman, said: "It’s building a hugely important platform for future victories.” But elsewhere Vince Cable’s party showed no signs of enjoying the sort of recovery that would see it turn into a strong force at Westminster.

Catastrophic night for 'Black Death' Ukip

Ukip's vote collapsed and by Friday morning it held just two seats, 44 down on four years ago. General secretary Paul Oakley tried to put a brave face on things by comparing the party to the Black Death. "It's not all over at all," he told BBC Radio 4's Today programme. "Think of the Black Death in the Middle Ages. It comes along and it causes disruption and then it goes dormant, and that's exactly what we are going to do. Our time isn't finished because Brexit is being betrayed." Dan Sabbagh and Andrew Sparrow

media.title: I knew Rangers was the right move for me, says Steven Gerrard – video
media.description:
Steven Gerrard, the new Rangers manager, says he got a 'different feeling' in his stomach when he found out the Scottish side were interested. The former Liverpool midfielder has signed a four-year deal at Ibrox

Steven Gerrard appointed as new Rangers manager: 'It was a no-brainer'

tags: steven gerrard signs four year deal rangers

media.trailText: Steven Gerrard, the new Rangers manager, says he got a 'different feeling' in his stomach when he found out the Scottish side were interested. The former Liverpool midfielder has signed a four-year deal at Ibrox

results.title: I knew Rangers was the right move for me, says Steven Gerrard – video

results.title: Test-video

results.defaultHtml:
1. “With so many trees in the city, you could see the spring coming each day until a night of warm wind would bring it suddenly in one morning." Which city inspired this quote?

    1. Bristol

    2. Vancouver

    3. Singapore

    4. Paris

  2. "I love your criminal alleyways / Your dagger-like moon upon the hills,” wrote the Chilean poet Pablo Neruda. Which city was he describing?

    1. Valparaíso

    2. Bogotá

    3. Sintra

    4. Medellín

  3. On clear days, in which city can you see "beyond some low houses and walls of tufa and patches of thick vegetation, a blue mountain with one low peak and one a little higher"?

    1. Rome

    2. Naples

    3. Athens

    4. Palermo

  4. It was "once fashionable to say how dull it was", but now it's seen as "New York without the garbage and muggings". Which North American city is being discussed?

    1. Chicago

    2. Toronto

    3. Vancouver

    4. Seattle

  5. "For the city's more sensitive and attuned residents, these ruins are reminders that the present city is so poor and confused that it can never again dream of rising to the same heights of wealth, power and culture." Which historic is this?

    1. Damascus

    2. Istanbul

    3. Athens

    4. Rome

  6. Which city is the subject of this quote from a famous US playwright? "In this part of [the city] you are practically always just around the corner, or a few door down the street, from a tinny piano being played ..."

    1. San Francisco

    2. New Orleans

    3. New York City

    4. Atlanta

  7. Which author described an area of London in the following way? "Ungentrified, ungentrifiable. Boom and bust never came here. Here bust is permanent …"

    1. Iain Sinclair

    2. George Orwell

    3. Zadie Smith

    4. Martin Amis

  8. Which city is said to be "always dual"? "Houses are alleys; car thieves are the people to help you when your car won't start; pollution simultaneously chokes you and makes you gasp at the beauty of unnatural sunset."

    1. Karachi

    2. Lahore

    3. Islamabad

    4. Cairo

  9. "The giant digital screens fastened to the sides of buildings fall silent as midnight approaches, but loudspeakers on storefronts keep pumping out exaggerated hip-hop bass lines. A large game centre crammed with young people; wild electronic sounds; a group of college students spilling out from a bar ... dark-suited men racing across diagonal crosswalks for the last trains to the suburbs ..." Which city is full of late-night energy?

    1. Las Vegas

    2. New York City

    3. Tokyo

    4. Berlin

  10. Which city is being described here? "At first [the city] assaulted her; the sun-dazed haste, the yellow buses full of squashed limbs, the sweating hawkers racing after cars, the advertisements on hulking billboards ...”

    1. Baltimore

    2. New Delhi

    3. London

    4. Lagos

  11. Which war-torn city is this? "... the shell-blasted schools, the squatters living in roofless buildings, the beggars, the mud, the fickle electricity, but it's like describing music. He cannot bring it to life. [The city's] vivid, arresting details – the bodybuilding gym amid the rubble, for instance, a painting of Schwarzenegger on the window ..."

    1. Aleppo

    2. Mosul

    3. Gaza

    4. Kabul

  12. "This is a city of half-crazy people ... there are few places where you'll find so many gloomy, harsh and strange influences on the soul of a man ..." A 19th-century Russian literary giant is less than complimentary about which city?

    1. Moscow

    2. St Petersburg

    3. Vienna

    4. Kiev

  13. Where are the characters of an Irvine Welsh novel when they "go fir a pish in the auld Central Station at the Fit ay the Walk, now a barren, desolate hangar, which is soon tae be demolished and replaced by a supermarket and swimming centre"?

    1. Glasgow

    2. Leith

    3. Aberdeen

    4. Dundee

  14. Which city is this poem about? "We make brilliant music. We make brilliant bands / We make goals that make souls leap from seats in the stands / And we make things from steel and we make things from cotton / And we make people laugh, take the mick summat rotten."

    1. Manchester

    2. Newcastle

    3. Liverpool

    4. Sheffield

Solutions

1:D - From Ernest Hemingway's memoir A Moveable Feast. Hemingway's travels are deeply embedded in his most famous works – from The Sun Also Rises, set in Pamplona, to The Old Man and the Sea, written in Havana – but he is most associated with the French capital, 2:A - Taken from Neruda's Canto General. The poet had a house in Valparaíso, named La Sebastiana, and wrote that if "we walk up and down all the stairs of Valparaíso we’ll have walked all round the world", 3:B - The passage is taken from My Brilliant Friend, the first of Elena Ferrante's Neapolitan novels. The city itself is almost like a character in her books, 4:B - From the 1988 novel Cat's Eye by Margaret Atwood, who is based in Toronto. The influential Canadian writer has more than 40 books of poetry, fiction and essays to her name, 5:B - The passage is from Istanbul: Memories and the City, a memoir by the Turkish Nobel-winner Orhan Pamuk, 6:B - Here, Tennessee Williams sets the scene for his 1947 play A Streetcar Named Desire, 7:C - The passage is about Kilburn, from Zadie Smith's 2012 novel NW, which traces the lives of four characters who grew up in the same part of north-west London, 8:A - Kamila Shamsie's Kartography is set in the 70s and 80s in Pakistan's largest city, and follows the story of two inseparable children. Shamsie was raised in Karachi and now lives in London, 9:C - Haruki Murakami's 2004 novel After Dark is set in Tokyo's nocturnal downtown entertainment district, Shinjuku, 10:D - Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie's 2013 novel Americanah is the story of a young Nigerian woman who goes to university in the United States. The author was born in Enugu, a city in south-eastern Nigera, 11:D - From And the Mountains Echoed, a 2013 novel by the Afghan-American author Khaled Hosseini, 12:B - Fyodor Dostoevsky's philosophical novel was originally published in 1866, 13:B - Welsh’s Trainspotting was first published in 1993. It follows a group of friends and heroin users in the 1980s living in Leith, a deprived district in the north of Edinburgh on the cusp of regeneration, 14:A - From This Is the Place, by local poet Tony Walsh (AKA Longfella). He performed the poem, dedicated to the city, at the vigil for the victims of the Manchester Arena attack in May 2017

Scores

  1. 13 and above.

    Excellent

  2. 14 and above.

    Excellent!

  3. 12 and above.

    Well done

  4. 11 and above.

    Well done

  5. 10 and above.

    Well done

  6. 9 and above.

    Well done

  7. 8 and above.

    OK

  8. 7 and above.

    OK

  9. 6 and above.

    Not great

  10. 5 and above.

    Poor

  11. 4 and above.

    Poor

  12. 3 and above.

    Hmmm

  13. 2 and above.

    Hmmm

  14. 1 and above.

    Oh dear

  15. 0 and above.

    Oh dear

answers.revealText: From Ernest Hemingway's memoir A Moveable Feast. Hemingway's travels are deeply embedded in his most famous works – from The Sun Also Rises, set in Pamplona, to The Old Man and the Sea, written in Havana – but he is most associated with the French capital

answers.revealText: Fyodor Dostoevsky's philosophical novel was originally published in 1866

questions.questionText: Where are the characters of an Irvine Welsh novel when they "go fir a pish in the auld Central Station at the Fit ay the Walk, now a barren, desolate hangar, which is soon tae be demolished and replaced by a supermarket and swimming centre"?

answers.revealText: Welsh’s Trainspotting was first published in 1993. It follows a group of friends and heroin users in the 1980s living in Leith, a deprived district in the north of Edinburgh on the cusp of regeneration

questions.questionText:
Which city is this poem about? 

"We make brilliant music. We make brilliant bands /

We make goals that make souls leap from seats in the stands /

And we make things from steel and we make things from cotton /

And we make people laugh, take the mick summat rotten."

answers.revealText: From This Is the Place, by local poet Tony Walsh (AKA Longfella). He performed the poem, dedicated to the city, at the vigil for the victims of the Manchester Arena attack in May 2017

media.title: Trump on Giuliani: 'He'll get his facts straight' on Stormy Daniels – video
media.description:
The US president tells reporters that the former New York mayor, who joined the president’s legal team last month, will 'get his facts straight' eventually. Giuliani said earlier this week that Trump had personally reimbursed his lawyer Michael Cohen for a $130,000 payment made to Stormy Daniels 

  • Donald Trump says Giuliani yet to get his 'facts straight' on Stormy Daniels
media.trailText: Donald Trump says his lawyer Rudy Giuliani will get his facts straight on the Stormy Daniels scandal

results.title: Trump on Giuliani: 'He'll get his facts straight' on Stormy Daniels – video
